reference.title: <troubleshooting> model
reference.shortdesc: This topic describes the structure and the semantics used in the <troubleshooting> specialization.

section.title: <troubleshooting> children
section.p: The <troubleshooting> specializes <topic>. Except for <body>, all top-level elements available in <topic> are also available in <troubleshooting>. The <troublebody> specializes the <body> element and takes the <body> element's place in <troubleshooting>.

The info-types available following <troublebody> are restricted to <task>. This allows writers to embed complete <task> topics within <troubleshooting> topics instead of using <remedy> elements. <troubleshooting> is deliberately excluded from the info-types to discourage complexity.
As with info-types in other topic types, topic composition through <topicref> elements in the DITA map is preferable. Implementors may wish to disable this option from a shell DTD.

section.title: <troublebody> children
section.p: <troublebody> contains a mix of <cause>, <condition>, <remedy>, and <troublebodydiv> elements.

section.title: <troublebodydiv> children
section.p: <troublebodydiv> contains a mix of <cause>, <condition>, and <remedy> elements.

section.title: <cause>
section.p: This element indicates the cause of whatever problem might exist. <cause> specializes the <section> element in name only. This means that <cause> and <section> have identical content models.

section.title: <condition>
section.p: This element describes conditions, symptoms, or states associated with the problem. <condition> specializes the <section> element in name only.

section.title: <remedy>
section.p: This element describes a resolution for the problem. <remedy> specializes the <section> element. <remedy> begins with an optional <title> element, then allows all block-level children of <section>, followed by an optional choice of either the <steps> element or the <steps-unordered> element from <task>. The steps can optionally be followed more block-level children of <section>.
Writers should select <remedy> over embedded <task> especially when multiple cause-solution pairs exist for the same troubleshooting condition.

section.title: Embedded tasks
section.p: Embedded tasks may be used when the semantic elements of <task> (such as <context>, <preqreq>, or <result>) are necessary. Some reuse scenarios may also warrant the use of embedded tasks. Writers are encouraged to choose <remedy> over <task> when possible. Writers should embed tasks from the DITA map, with chunking, instead of putting the tasks directly into the topic. Embedded tasks cannot be presented in pairs the <cause> element when multiple cause-solution combinations exist because the tasks are only allowed after of the <troublebody> element.
